title: Considering chapter 7, pro-bono in san diego,ca. only source of income. May I wave the filing fee's?
question: I've accumulated too much debt. all unsecured. I once filled chapter 7 in Humboldt County Ca. in 1975. back then there was a "pauper petition" to wave filing fee's.
answers: Other considerations: waiver of court fees effects subsidizing of court costs and nonpayment to the case trustee. The fee-waiver application considers a totality of circumstances including, but not limited to income-level and assets. Beyond satisfying threshold criteria, the debtor must ultimately declare under penalty of perjury that they cannot afford the filing fee.

You can file for a waiver:

1. The court can say yes if your income and assets are minimal. You would have to look at the form or check the court web site for the limits on income and assets. A link to the form is below:

http://www.casb.uscourts.gov/html/csdforms/CSD1020.pdf

2. The court can say no, in which case you will have to pay the fee within 30 - 45 days (as I recall) in two payments.

BW

You can file a motion to waive the filing fee, which the court reviews based on your income. You motion can be granted only if your income is less than 150% of the poverty line income for a family of your size. Here's a link to the 2011 poverty guidelines: http://www.uscourts.gov/FederalCourts/Bankruptcy/BankruptcyResources/PovertyGuidelines.aspx. If your motion is denied, the judge may ask you to pay your filing fee in monthly installments. Be sure to make the installment payments on time or your case will be dismissed.

Yes. There are two different options, depending on which you can qualify for. At the courthouse in San Diego, or online, you can get copies of the following two forms:

Application to Pay Filing Fees in Installments - Form # CSD 1006
and
Application for Waiver of Chapter 7 Filing Fee - Form # CSD 1020

The forms themselves have instructions on them, including financial worksheet information, that will explain what is required to qualify for one or the other. You can read them both and then you will be able to determine, based on your situation, which one, if either, you may be able to qualify for.
